title: A new study reveals doctors fear the US opioid epidemic will be replaced by a new prescription drug crisis
text:
This story was delivered to Business Insider Intelligence Digital Health Pro subscribers earlier this morning.

To get this story plus others to your inbox each day, hours before they're published on Business Insider, click here

A new study from Quest Diagnostics delivers several alarming insights into the scope and threat posed by the US' opioid epidemic — which claims the lives of 130 people every day — including the fact that 62% of physicians fear the opioid crisis will be traded for a new prescription drug crisis or higher use of illicit narcotics.

Business Insider Intelligence

While doctors walk a thin line between wanting to prescribe effective pain treatment and concerns over drug abuse, 72% of physicians fear that if chronic disease patients don't have access to opioids, they'll turn to illicit drugs instead.

And there doesn't seem to be a clear pharmacological substitute for the 20% of US adults living with chronic pain: Nearly 80% of doctors say that they often prescribe the drug gabapentin for pain management as an alternative to opioids, but misuse of that medication rose 40% between 2017 and 2018.

Further, physicians may not be as prepared as they think when it comes to spotting signs of misuse: 83% of physicians believe they're able to adequately screen for prescription drug misuse, yet more than half of all patient test results processed by Quest Diagnostics for prescription drug monitoring showed signs of misuse.

And while it's promising to know that major health CEOs were summoned to federal court on Friday for their roles in the opioid epidemic— litigation doesn't bring the healthcare system any closer to a chronic pain solution.

Even as some of the nation's largest names in healthcare appear in federal court in attempts to settle more than 2,000 opioid related lawsuits aimed at holding drugmakers, distributors, and pharmacies responsible through a potential $50 billion settlement — relief for the families and communities that have been devastated by the opioid crisis feels defiantly out of reach.

While there's no silver bullet to resolve the opioid crisis, docs' overwhelming concerns regarding a new drug crisis could open the pathways for digital alternatives:

Digital health startups like Oska Wellness and Kaia Health have built their products as alternatives to pharma-driven pain management. California-based Oska Wellness uses what it calls Pulsed Electromagnetic Field (PEMF) technology in its Oska Pulse wearable device, and the company raised over $5 million in early stage funding this past June to help scale the business. And digital therapeutics startup Kaia Health raked in $10 million earlier this year for an app-based approach to physiotherapy for musculoskeletal (MSK) disorders, which often comes with chronic pain.

And providers and startups alike are exploring virtual reality (VR) therapies for pain relief. A recent study from Cedars-Sinai illustrated the potential for VR to manage pain levels of their patients — as patients who were provided with on-demand, bedside access to relaxing VR experiences reported statistically significant decreases in their pain levels compared with the control group. And researchers from the University of Phoenix found that 77% of patients who engaged with VR experiences during labor reported that it helped them manage their pain.
